author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Geoffrey Nunberg, Expert on How Language Works, Dies at 75
description: A widely respected linguist, he found popularity beyond academia with appearances on NPR and books like the intriguingly titled “Going Nucular.”
content: Geoffrey Nunberg, a linguist whose elegant essays and books explained to a general audience how English has adapted to changes in politics, popular culture and technology, died on Aug. 11 at his home in San Francisco. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Why Biden Needs a Landslide Just to Win
description: Only a lopsided show of force would overcome undelivered mail, closed polling sites and Trump’s schemes.
content: When many of us question Hillary Clinton’s performance and strategy in 2016 and say that she should have won, we’re speaking sloppily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Another Putin Critic Apparently Poisoned
description: Will the West take action against whoever may have harmed Aleksei Navalny?
content: Aleksei Navalny — reportedly still in a coma — has finally been allowed to fly to Germany for treatment, so at least the mystery of what caused Russia’s most prominent opposition figure to collapse in terrible agony on a flight over Siberia may be resolved. But if it does turn out to be poison, to which all signs point, it will still not explain who attacked him or why.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Felt Sick in March? Antibody Test Won’t Tell Much
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 22, 2020.
content: “If you were sick back in March you probably don’t have antibodies anymore, and if you were only mildly sick you may not have gotten antibodies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Hangout for Dorian Gray
description: Trenton Charlson steals a little of our youth.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a tough one, and an example of what the street fashion bloggers call “high-low,” a mingling of very opulent clues that require knowledge of opulent things and some nice commercial mentions for hoi polloi. Here’s a weird hint: There are no Zs nor any Qs, which is very strange for a Trenton Charlson puzzle. Every other letter is accounted for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Jane Callister
title: Sharpen a Pencil and Challenge an Opponent
description: These seemingly simple pencil-and-paper games were all invented by mathematicians. They call for two players and some strategic thinking.
content: First published in the 19th century by the French mathematician Édouard Lucas, Dots and Boxes was called La Pipopipette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Morris and Jana Bennett
title: We Are Living With Brain Cancer. Here’s How Biden Could Help Us.
description: Like Beau Biden, we have glioblastoma. It doesn’t get the attention it should.
content: If Joe Biden reaches the White House, he will have more direct experience with cancer than most presidents. His eldest son, Beau Biden, died in 2015, at 46 from glioblastoma, the most aggressive form of primary brain cancer. Glioblastoma is deadly — median survival from time of diagnosis is only 14 months — and notoriously difficult to treat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bortz
title: Wedding Canceled or Postponed? Here’s How to Get a Refund
description: For many couples whose wedding plans were derailed by the coronavirus crisis, getting a refund or a credit from vendors has been an uphill battle.
content: Frank Dariano and Sharon Mensah had planned to marry on July 5, with 50 guests in attendance, at a resort in Banff National Park in the Rocky Mountains of Alberta, Canada. But they canceled the wedding shortly after shelter-in-place orders were issued in San Jose, Calif., their hometown. “Our plans really went south as the pandemic started cracking down on international travel,” said Mr. Dariano, an administrative assistant at an outpatient rehabilitation center in Sunnyvale, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Sister Elaine Roulet, 89, Dies; Aided Imprisoned Mothers and Their Children
description: Changes Sister Elaine helped bring about at the Bedford Hills prison for women in New York State allowed inmates and their offspring to bond.
content: Sister Elaine Roulet, a Roman Catholic nun who helped female inmates bond with their children and created innovative programs for mothers both in prison and after release, died on Aug. 13 at the Stella Maris Convent in the Rockaway Park section of Queens. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Fleeing the Trolls for the Grizzly Bears
description: When “civilization” oppresses, wilderness is the best therapy.
content: PACIFIC NORTHWEST TRAIL, Mont. — What’s a person to do in a crazy summer when our president endorses a candidate who claims the world is controlled by a “global cabal of Satan-worshiping pedophiles,” when federal agents club a Navy veteran protesting peacefully, when the government delays postal services to impede voting (and thereby kills chicks sent in the mail)?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Covid in the Classroom? Some Schools Are Keeping It Quiet
description: Some states and school districts provide detailed data on school outbreaks. Others choose to keep such information under wraps.
content: On the first day of school in Camden County, Ga., local Facebook groups were already buzzing with rumors that a teacher had tested positive for the coronavirus. The next day, a warning went out to school administrators: Keep teachers quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Bold Red Lipstick Is a Political Uniform, Too
description: Running for office used to mean relegating personal style to the background. Not anymore.
content: Forget pearls, go for the hoops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: I’ve Been Away From My Apartment for Months. What Happens Now?
description: Courts have long held that tenants can stay away from their apartments for extended periods because of health reasons. But don’t neglect your home.
content: Q: I live in an Upper East Side apartment with a rent-stabilized lease, which requires me to live there at least 183 days a year. I have been away since the start of the pandemic. What happens if I stay away for more than half the year? And how do I maintain it in the meantime?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Tropical Storms Marco and Laura Both Headed to the Gulf of Mexico
description: It is possible that both storms would become hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico as early as Monday.
content: Tropical Storms Marco and Laura continued to churn in the Caribbean on Saturday, prompting a wave of warnings and watches for several countries, and leading the governor of Louisiana to declare a state of emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, here with a cryptic? Double happiness.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — It’s always a treat to get a Cox/Rathvon creation on an off week. Those of us who solve the acrostic have an advantage, as we are already on these constructors’ sophisticated and funny wavelength, but you don’t need a fancy surfboard or nerves of steel to hop on — the water is warm, and if you see a shark, just maintain eye contact and soldier on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Natalie Grono
title: ‘A Bit Surreal’: The Lonely Plight of the Great Barrier Reef
description: The tourism operators who depend on the natural wonder, already contending with climate change, have been walloped by the pandemic. The absence of visitors is bad for them — and the reef.
content: CAIRNS, Australia — Diving beneath the ocean, Russell Hosp swam toward the limestone bed of the Great Barrier Reef, where he reattached bits of blue staghorn coral. With tourists gone, he was filling the void with this small act of conservation, which took his mind off the uncertain future on land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Is the ‘Convention Bounce’ a Thing of the Past?
description: After the Democratic primary campaign came to an abrupt halt in late March as the coronavirus swept through the nation, the Democrats and Republicans have looked to the conventions as their candidates’ biggest stage.
content: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Iyad Abuheweila
title: 11-Year-Old Scores Viral Rap Hit but Trips on Gaza Politics
description: Abdel Rahman al-Shantti became a Palestinian rap star when his video went viral. His trouble began when he advocated “love between us and Israel.”
content: JERUSALEM — When the 11-year-old schoolboy from Gaza posted a video of himself rapping the lyrics of one of his favorite artists, he never expected it would make him famous or get him in trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By María Silvia Trigo, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Allison McCann
title: As Politicians Clashed, Bolivia’s Pandemic Death Rate Soared
description: Bolivia was mired in political turmoil when the pandemic hit. The response was chaotic. And the surge in deaths that followed was among the worst in the world, according to an analysis by The New York Times.
content: TARIJA, Bolivia — So many people were dying that the government’s numbers couldn’t be accurate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Global Death Toll From Virus Surpasses 800,000
description: The pandemic is increasingly lethal in South America. Three U.S. states find cases linked to the Sturgis motorcycle rally. A judge blocks a couple’s 175-guest wedding in New York.
content: The global death toll from the coronavirus surpassed 800,000 on Saturday, according to data compiled by The New York Times, as new infections flared in Europe and high numbers of deaths were recorded across the United States, India, South Africa and most of Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Coronavirus Limits California’s Efforts to Fight Fires With Prison Labor
description: Early releases of prisoners to protect them from the virus have depleted the ranks of an inmate firefighting program that some say should be abolished anyway.
content: VACAVILLE, Calif. — They charge into fire zones with 60-pound packs and three-foot chain saws, felling trees and hacking through brush to make wide paths of dirt around anything worth protecting. Bright orange uniforms set them apart from other firefighters — and identify them as inmates of California’s state prisons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Fingersh
title: How to Set Pandemic Boundaries for Relatives
description: You’d do anything for them in a crisis, but the crisis isn’t going away. Here’s how to get your life back.
content: When pandemic-related shutdowns started, many people rushed to the rescue of their loved ones. They rallied to meet an extraordinary situation and extended themselves in deep and loving ways. They welcomed home adult children with open arms. They jumped to babysit for their grandkids. They volunteered to shop for neighbors and elderly relatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
title: How can the G.O.P. top the D.N.C.?
description: The Biden granddaughters were lovely. Shorter speeches were effective. The travelogue roll call made for strangely good TV.
content: The Biden granddaughters were lovely. Shorter speeches were effective. The travelogue roll call made for strangely good TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Stop Campus Partying to Slow the Virus? Colleges Try but Often Fail
description: Coronavirus outbreaks at colleges reopening for fall classes underscore the difficulties of policing student behavior.
content: At Cornell University, students started arriving over the past week hoping for a safe and socially distanced fall semester. Jason Chang already has doubts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: How Teenage Activists Are Talking to Family About Racial Injustice
description: After organizing online, sharing resources and marching in their towns, many young people have kept conversations about racism and change going at home.
content: At dinner tables, chatter keeps turning to the treatment of Black Americans. In living rooms, U.S. history becomes fodder for debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Brennan is told he is not a target of criminal inquiry into Russia investigation.
description: The former C.I.A. director John O. Brennan was told during eight hours of questioning on Friday that he was not the target of any criminal inquiry as part of a divisive Justice Department examination into the Russia investigation’s origins.
content: The former C.I.A. director John O. Brennan was told during eight hours of questioning on Friday that he was not the target of any criminal inquiry as part of a divisive Justice Department examination into the Russia investigation’s origins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Why Some Tropical Fish Are Gettin’ Squiggly With It
description: On occasion, different species of angelfish produce hybrid offspring even more colorful than the parents.
content: When American painter Bob Ross said, “There are no mistakes, only happy accidents,” he was ostensibly referring to paint on a canvas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Navalny, Being Treated in Germany, Looms Over Russian Politics
description: His sudden, unexplained illness comes amid political uprisings in Russia’s Far East, and just weeks before municipal elections take place across the country.
content: BERLIN — Russia’s most prominent opposition figure, Aleksei A. Navalny, arrived in Berlin for treatment on Saturday after falling into a coma in Siberia in what his family and supporters suspect was a deliberate poisoning weeks before nationwide local elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Emily Cochrane
title: House Votes to Block Postal Changes and Allocate Funds for Mail
description: The Democratic bill would send $25 billion to the Postal Service and reverse changes that have slowed service until after November’s election.
content: WASHINGTON — The House interrupted its summer recess on Saturday for a rare weekend session to approve legislation blocking cost-cutting and operational changes at the Postal Service that Democrats, civil rights advocates and some Republicans fear could jeopardize mail-in ballots this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: 5 Podcasts to Bring Theater Into Your Home
description: Many theater companies are closed, but that doesn’t mean you can’t immerse yourself in the magic of a play.
content: In the United States, stages mostly remain dark. But there is another option for finding that full immersion into the magic of the theater, and that’s through podcasts. These shows, available on most listening apps, will challenge the assumption that you need to be in a theater seat to be transported into another world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Five weeks after a runoff, a Cruz-backed House candidate concedes defeat in Texas.
description: Five weeks after a too-close-to-call Republican primary runoff in a Southwest Texas congressional district, Raul Reyes, a retired Air Force colonel, has abandoned a recount and conceded defeat to Tony Gonzales, a former Navy cryptologist, by a handful of votes.
content: Five weeks after a too-close-to-call Republican primary runoff in a Southwest Texas congressional district, Raul Reyes, a retired Air Force colonel, has abandoned a recount and conceded defeat to Tony Gonzales, a former Navy cryptologist, by a handful of votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A Glimmer of Hope for Trump? How Bush Mounted a Comeback in 1988
description: For Biden, a cautionary tale. For Trump, a negative strategy for rebounding in a race.
content: George H.W. Bush was in trouble. It was July 1988 and Michael Dukakis, the Democratic candidate for president, was on a roll after his party’s convention in Atlanta. A Gallup poll showed Mr. Bush trailing by 17 points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Treat Yourself to Good Advice and Pudding
description: Stream a podcast full of pro tips, tune in for story time and a snack tutorial — or host a murder-mystery party.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Make Bulgogi Chicken and Mushrooms Now
description: Or try Judy Kim’s chile-oil noodles and Lidey Heuck’s peaches and cream pie.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Kay Chun’s chicken and mushroom bulgogi lettuce wraps (above), Lidey Heuck’s peaches and cream pie and Judy Kim’s chile-oil noodles with cilantro. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Yee
title: Recognize Misinformation on the Internet
description: Identifying reliable information online is especially urgent, and especially for seniors.
content: Older people are vulnerable to misinformation online even under normal circumstances. But the coronavirus has made the problem especially urgent. Older people are more susceptible to the virus, making discerning reliable health information important now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Alan Rappeport and Hailey Fuchs
title: Mnuchin Paved Way for Postal Service Shake-Up
description: At President Trump’s behest, the Treasury Secretary sought out appointees who would restructure the United States Postal Service.
content: WASHINGTON — In early February, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin invited two Republican members of the Postal Service’s board of governors to his office to update him on a matter in which he had taken a particular interest — the search for a new postmaster general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg
title: Texas Republicans Say New Slogan Was Inspired by Poem, Not QAnon
description: Party officials in Texas said that the internet-driven conspiracy theory had nothing to do with its use of the slogan “We Are the Storm” — one of the chief rallying cries for QAnon adherents.
content: Facing questions about its use of the slogan “We Are the Storm,” a rallying cry for QAnon adherents, the Texas Republican Party is defending its adoption of the language, saying it was drawn from a poem and had nothing to do with the internet-driven conspiracy theory that claims President Trump was elected to save America from pedophile Satanists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Military Surveillance Planes Didn’t Spy on Protesters, Pentagon Report Finds
description: But the Air Force’s inspector general concluded that National Guard officials failed to obtain prior approval from Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper to use the planes.
content: WASHINGTON — Deploying a little-known National Guard reconnaissance plane in four American cities to monitor protests this spring did not violate rules against the military collecting intelligence on citizens, a Pentagon report has concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Musical Interlude
description: Barbara Lin’s puzzle hits all of the right notes.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Solving this puzzle is such a pleasure, if it hits your brain the way it did mine and evokes a happy tune. Barbara Lin is a computer engineer, as well as a constructor — this is her third Times puzzle and her Sunday debut. Designing a bit of useful code, filling in every box in a crossword and following a bit of harmonious music are among the satisfying “clicks” that our minds can make. It amazes me when these experiences play off each other (and don’t miss the constructor’s notes for further elaboration on that).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Joe’s Fearsome Weapon Against Trump: Simple Decency
description: Biden takes on Donnie Darkness and promises to bring us into the light.
content: WASHINGTON — Whenever I called my mom to tell her something bad had happened, she said, “I know.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Merchandise Bundles Undid the Album Chart
description: For today’s biggest artists, an album release isn’t just about the music.
content: Approximately half the albums that have topped the Billboard album chart since the beginning of 2019 have been made available as part of a bundle, in which it is offered as an add-on sale to a more expensive item, typically an article of clothing or a concert ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Geneva Abdul
title: Greece … or Devon? Camping Outshines Continent for Britons This Summer
description: With many vacationers reluctant to go abroad because of the pandemic, “for the first time in the U.K., owning a caravan is kind of cool.”
content: LONDON — This summer, Louise Towers and her partner are loading their four children and Nellie the dog into a camper van for their annual holiday. It’s an honored tradition: Each of the past five summers, they took a road trip through continental Europe in a home-on-wheels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Win or Lose, Trump Will Hold Power Over the G.O.P.
description: But what Republicans learn from the Trump era will make all the difference.
content: It must pain Donald Trump, deep down in his showman’s soul, to have had his convention taken away from him. The arguable peak of his presidency, the hubristic State of the Union that preceded the coronavirus, raised the reality-television elements of the address to new heights — reuniting a military family! Bestowing a Presidential Medal of Freedom! You can only imagine what brazen gimmicks, what WWE stagecraft, Trump would have rolled out for a convention taking place in normal times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: A Spanish Whistle-Blower Appeals to the E.U. for Help
description: Roberto Macías is invoking a new European Union law protecting whistle-blowers to argue that he should not have been convicted after exposing corruption in Spain.
content: SEVILLE, Spain — He leaked files that led to the prosecution of one of the biggest labor corruption scandals in Spain’s history. But instead of being lauded for whistle-blowing, he was charged with revealing workplace secrets and sentenced to two years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Cartilage Is Grown in the Arthritic Joints of Mice
description: Researchers discovered a way to awaken dormant stem cells and transform them into cartilage. If the technique works in humans, it may help ease debilitating joint pain.
content: The painful knees and hips experienced by so many people with osteoarthritis result from a loss of cartilage, which serves as a sort of cushioning in the joints. It had long been thought that cartilage, once gone, cannot grow back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
title: Trump’s Approval Rating, Biden’s Low Bar: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: The Democratic National Convention, on the whole, was aimed more at appealing to moderates than rallying the base. Will the Republicans take the opposite approach?
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: Make and Jar Pomodoro to Last All Year Long
description: Who knows what the rest of 2020 will bring, but at least you’ll have quality pasta sauce to enjoy just like Nonna used to make.
content: August and early September is the ideal time to finally pick those plump tomatoes that you’ve spent all season tending (or eyeing at the supermarket). With a bit more patience and forearm endurance, you can enjoy the actual fruits of your labor for longer by cooking up and jarring a naturally sweet, homemade tomato sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Justice Dept. Questions Former C.I.A. Director for 8 Hours
description: John O. Brennan is a witness, not a target, in the inquiry being led by John H. Durham, a U.S. attorney, but the C.I.A. under Barack Obama could be subject to further criticism by the Trump administration.
content: WASHINGTON — The former C.I.A. director John O. Brennan was told during eight hours of questioning on Friday that he was not the target of any criminal inquiry as part of a divisive Justice Department examination into the Russia investigation’s origins.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 22, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 22, 2020.
content: An article on Thursday about the reopening of Florida schools referred incorrectly to Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach Counties. They are the three largest counties in Florida; they do not have the state’s three largest school districts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Finally Organize Those Photos
description: Sorting your photographs, whether digital or print or both, can seem daunting. Here are some simple ways to catalog and organize your images.
content: Spending more time at home has offered the opportunity to tackle all sorts of ambitious projects, from D.I.Y. focaccia to work-space upgrades. Yet there’s one task that still seems impossible: organizing hundreds, if not thousands — or even hundreds of thousands — of print and digital photographs. The idea of sorting through them feels daunting, so instead you do nothing. The shots pile up; the cycle continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: UPS Driver Charged in a Series of Shootings on an Oregon Highway
description: Officials said Kenneth Ayers fired at vehicles from a UPS tractor-trailer on seven separate occasions starting in May. A motive for the shootings, which injured one person, was unknown.
content: A driver for UPS was arrested on Thursday in connection with a series of shootings along a highway in southwest Oregon that injured one person and unnerved motorists, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Future of the G.O.P. After Trump
description: Readers discuss a column by David Brooks, who argued that a group of senators in their 40s embody the party’s future.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Ana Swanson
title: TikTok to Challenge Trump Administration Over Executive Order
description: The popular video app, which is owned by a Chinese internet company, said it had been deprived of due process when President Trump moved to block it in the United States.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — TikTok plans to sue the United States government, the company confirmed on Saturday, arguing that President Trump’s moves to block the app had deprived it of due process and claiming it had been unfairly and incorrectly treated as a security threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: The Coronavirus Generation
description: The virus doesn’t sicken kids as much as adults. But it can still destroy their futures. A child allowance would help.
content: Three decades ago, a team of researchers at Duke University set off to follow a group of schoolchildren in a stretch of rural North Carolina that happened to include a small reservation. Soon after, the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians opened a casino and began sharing the profits, about $4,000 per adult each year, with every household in the tribe — essentially creating a local version of guaranteed income.
source.name: The New York Times

title: If Storms Hit California, Blazes May Be Tougher to Control
description: Two groups of wildfires have swelled to become the second- and third-largest blazes the state has seen.
content: California firefighters had good weather on their side on Saturday as they battled wildfires that have torched nearly one million acres and forced the evacuation of more than 119,000 people from their homes. But their fortune may run out on Sunday, when storms with strong winds, lightning and little rain may return to the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Lamenting the loss of the in-person convention.
description: I’ve attended every convention since 1988, when Michael J. Dukakis accepted the Democratic presidential nomination. That year, as I exited Atlanta’s rapidly emptying Omni Coliseum after the balloons had dropped, I stopped to chat with a prominent Southern Democratic senator. He was all smiles, sure that the party’s four days of festivities would lead to Mr. Dukakis beating George H.W. Bush. Like thousands of other Democrats in attendance, he thought it was in the bag.
content: I’ve attended every convention since 1988, when Michael J. Dukakis accepted the Democratic presidential nomination. That year, as I exited Atlanta’s rapidly emptying Omni Coliseum after the balloons had dropped, I stopped to chat with a prominent Southern Democratic senator. He was all smiles, sure that the party’s four days of festivities would lead to Mr. Dukakis beating George H.W. Bush. Like thousands of other Democrats in attendance, he thought it was in the bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How to Reverse Course on Trump’s Environmental Damage
description: The next president can undo some of the recent efforts to weaken environmental protections. But it’ll take work.
content: That the Interior Department has now blessed oil and gas drilling in the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge comes as no surprise. It was a foregone conclusion once Lisa Murkowski, in 2017, persuaded her Senate colleagues to authorize drilling in the refuge as part of a tax bill, ending protections that have been in place since the Eisenhower administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: Crummy College Quarantine Food Goes Viral: A Lemon as a Side Dish?
description: Students arriving at N.Y.U. and other campuses are flooding social media with complaints about meals they are given as they isolate.
content: A lemon as a side dish. Some lettuce in a plastic bag. A sandwich for a student with gluten allergies. Salads with chicken for vegetarians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Gale
title: Swift Storm Left Iowa in Tatters
description: Nearly two weeks after a destructive derecho storm swept through the Midwest, residents of eastern Iowa are still digging themselves out.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — It is not unheard-of for Iowa to experience a tornado or a freak thunderstorm. It is also not unheard-of for my mother to exaggerate a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: In Year of Virtual Politics, Republican Delegates Flock to Charlotte Convention
description: It’s not the convention people will see on television next week. But Republicans are staging a truncated gathering in Charlotte to renominate President Trump.
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Shirlene Ostrov, the Republican state party chairman from Hawaii, has barely left her home in Mililani since March, because of the island’s rigorous stay-at-home order put in place to combat the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Toronto Raptors’ Nick Nurse Named N.B.A. Coach of the Year
description: Nurse received 90 percent of the first-place votes after leading the team to the No. 2 seed in the Eastern Conference.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Nick Nurse was announced as the winner of the N.B.A. Coach of the Year Award on Saturday after leading the defending champion Toronto Raptors to another 50-win season, this time without Kawhi Leonard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Belarus Blocks and Shutters News Outlets as Protests Swell
description: More than 50 news media websites have been blocked and two major newspapers have been closed as a government under fire sought to control the message.
content: MINSK, Belarus — Authorities in Belarus have blocked more than 50 news media websites reporting on how the country has been shaken by two weeks of protests demanding that President Alexander Lukashenko resign after 26 years in power.
source.name: The New York Times
